Meet the team




Andrew Purcell - CEO & Founder
Andrew has run a Wealth Management company for 25 years and is the Founder of Child Angel. He is at the forefront of the company and strives to achieve his heart’s desire of having an Angel look over your Child.




Clare Purcell - Company Director




Claire’s sales experience and organisational skills help to steer the Child Angel family and being a Mum she adds that real hands on protective instinct that is paramount to our focus.




David Wild - Marketing Manager



David adds over 25 years of financial advice, negotiation and experience at all levels and has a very level approach to resource and is a real asset to our team.





Graham Williams - Sales Manager



Graham brings over 30 years experience to Child Angel at Senior Management, HR and Director level and adds enormous value to our team.





Jenny Williams - Sales Executive


Jenny has had many years in office management and as a personal assistant to senior management and is the analyst and researcher that dots every ‘I’ and crosses all our ‘T’s’






Other Ways You Can Help

 
There are many ways to contribute! Even if you don't have the money right now, you can help us turn Child Angel into a reality by sharing this Indiegogo campaign with your friends. Just click on any of the Facebook, Twitter, and other sharing buttons let the world know about Child Angel and help us make a difference.

   
Thank you
Gabriel & Angelica
XXXXX




Look How Far We Have Come



















Kidzpod
See photo gallery









Questions & Answers

Q - Is there a danger with these devices
that they are relied on too heavily – should parents rely solely on Child
Angel™  to look after their children?
A- No, our product is aimed to create that
little extra feeling of knowing where our little ones are and it is not
designed to replace Parental Responsibility, merely to enhance it.
Parents should make sure that their
children understand the importance of being aware of the dangers around them,
particularly ‘stranger danger’, and Child Angel™  in no way detracts from
that message.
Q - Do you think that children should have
more independence and not be able to be traced as part of their daily
lives?  Do you think that this device may detract from their own coping
strategies?
A- Child Angel™ brings a little more
comfort to parents in the thought that out of sight does not mean children are
non-visible.  Children still need to develop their own strengths and weaknesses
to be able to feel confident in the real world but at the same time, parents
like to know where they are.
Q-  How can you assure parents that
the data concerning their child’s location will be treated in a secure manner?
A- Child Angel™ has been developed so that
only the parent/carer will ever have access to the child’s location.  With
our product the parent is in control: it is not a ‘phone or a text-enabled
device’ and the pairing is via a unique PIN recognition system that recycles
every time the Child Angel™  is reconnected, reducing the risk of unwanted
tracking.  This is also essential when used by the likes of theme parks,
sports clubs, shopping centres etc, to hire out on a daily basis.
Child Angel™  is designed so that the
position of the child can be securely reported back to a specific parent’s
phone or tablet. The device and service are optimised to provide position
reporting with a good balance of coverage performance, battery life, and
size/weight.

         Any additional questions please email us at
hello@child-angel.com

story:
Active Labour: 

Tuition & Funding

For my 'Holistic Doula' Certification

I'm the proud Mama of a 19 year old *Sun* who is truly my *Walking Resume*, my most important Life's Accomplishment.  He is my Heart outside of me, one of the Brightest Lights illumining my Sky.

I gave birth at home when it was a pretty rare and brave thing to do.  My Birth Initiation forever changed me, and I sensed one day I would Serve my Birthing Community because I understand what is truly possible when women are empowered~to~flower our own Birth Plans.

I am currently registered as a mature student at Pacific Rim College for the Holistic Doula Certification Program.  The word *Doula* originates from the Ancient Greek word δούλη which means 'female servant', and generally refers to 'a woman who is trained to assist another woman during childbirth'.  

I intend to be Birth’s trusted ally, its compassionate witness, a Guardian of Birth’s Truth, as it follows its meandering course so uniquely, so distinctly through each labouring woman I will assist as their Doula.  

In being well~prepared through impeccable training at PACIFIC RIM COLLEGE'S Holistic Doula Certification Program, and fortified with an exemplary education in birth mechanics and various labour~support techniques, I intend to stand as an empowered and informed world~bridger for all my si*stars crossing over birth’s threshold; She who releases her Past to birth our Future. 

This implies a sacred trust I strive to earn with humility.  I want to learn to be a caring & strong Doula Presence, consciously cultivated through direct, embodied experience.  I approach ‘becoming a doula’ as an intelligence of both mind and heart, coupled with an empathic knowing, so to translate action into grounded, integral principles and an honourable community~standing.  

I am enthusiastic to have been accepted as one of 16 fellow students for admission into Pacific Rim College's inspiring Holistic Doula program.  Prepared with skill, awareness and education, I intend to uphold a respected role as a birth advocate, one who can expand the awareness~spectrum of informed choice while accepting its honest outcome.  As a mature, integrated woman and mother who can hold engaged detachment during birth, while sustaining non~judgement for its unique course,  I will be a strong Doula in my Community.

Transition:

Because this is a full~time program which runs from September 2, 2014~ December 23, 2014, I require support to help *transition* me through the Birth Canal of my intensive study period.  My Tuition fee is $4000.CA,  and as well there are book/supply costs, transportation fees and living expenses. 

My schooling will be my "full~time job" until the end of 2014, and I may be asked to attend births as a volunteer Doula during my Practicum, as well.  

Crowning:

And a gift is not a gift until it is given away.  
What I comprehend of the trust, sanctity and mechanics of birth is a Knowledge which distils as Wisdom when it Blesses others in Service. Becoming a Doula is my GiveAway, my Medicine to Be Offered.  The women I hold space with will eventually shape me, slow and steady and purposeful as clay on a potter’s wheel, into my true Doula form, as I give back to life what it has given me: the conscious, feminine power to create. 

To be a Birther is to be gifted with precious guidance and ancient awareness of the Creational Mysteries.  To Birth is to be blessed a Maternal TimeKeeper, a Steward of the Rhythm and Pulse of Life.  It is both a subtle attunement and a rigorous rite of passage, to understand the pathways of Birth’s magnificent purpose and its response~ability.  It opens up the Heart’s indwelling intelligence, so that the sentience of life may know its place in one’s awareness and be allied to perception.  Its essence is Unity, its force, Diversity.

In supporting my Education Campaign to become a Certified Doula at Pacific Rim College, you will be indirectly contributing in the following ways:

  • My offering continuous support for women during childbirth as a Doula will support higher, more positive birth outcomes for future generationsl, as labouring women supported by a Doula are less likely to require pain relief medications & their side~effects, are less likely to endure the pain and recovery of a caesarean birth, and often feel they have experienced an overall more positive labour and delivery
  • My presence as a Doula may decrease the caesarean rate by 50%, the length of labor by 25%, the use of oxytocin by 40% and epidurals by 60% (from *Mothering the Mother* by Marshall H. Klaus )
  • My presence as a caring Doula will *buffer* the sometimes harsh influence of modern birthing environments, allowing my clients to relax more fully during *rushes* or contractions, which may help ease pain and shorten the overall length of labour
  • Peaceful birth environments promote a healthy, gentle emergence for babies to enter the world, without psycho~emotional birth~trauma imprints potentially impacting them in various ways throughout their lives

After~Birth:

With my vivacious entrepreneurial spirit, I intend to further weave together the strengths of my creative streams onto a *Blooming Loom* of Intention, in Service to the Victoria Birthing Community.

As well as working as a Doula, I envision:

~creating a line of pre/ post natal flower essences to support my Doula client's emotional needs

~Offering relaxing and rejuvenating Crystal Bowl Sound Healing Sessions for Mama and Baby

~Conducting Energy~Healing Sessions 

~Designing a Special *Birth Themed* line of Jewelry (belly strands, Blessing Way Beads…etc.)

~writing and publishing articles on Pregnancy, Birth and Motherhood

In conjunction with the extensive and comprehensive Doula training offered at Pacific Rim College, I feel I will be able to represent a high level of integrity, knowledge and keen awareness so to hold a conscious and empathic space for Birthing and Post~Partum women.   I would like to work in solidarity with the local *Doula Collective* or a similar convergence of birth advocates here in Victoria.

The Big *Push!* that got me OUT!:

Thank you for taking the time to be here and to read about my Campaign.  If you are unable to make a financial contribution to my Campaign at this time, please consider getting the word out to others who can!  Consider circulating my Campaign in your Social Media Networks and amongst those you may know, with the help of the various *share tools* provided here.

Alternately:

  • After the 30 day Campaign has expired consider making a regular, direct *Pay it Forward* Donation to my PayPal account, awakeningsolshine@gmail.com
  • Send a note or email wishing me luck and prosperity
  • Offer Prayers for success, peace and ease!
  • Hold High Intentions in your Heart, helping to CO~Create a Positive Outcome ;)

story:
Accessible Nature-based Learning for Ithaca-Area Children

Help us build nature-based learning opportunities for Ithaca-area children!

Last fall, the Lantern opened its doors, providing 14 homeschooled children with the opportunity to be a part of a community that emphasizes learning through a connection to the natural world and socialization through play.

The Lantern was launched by three families who poured their time, energy, and love into finding teachers, a space, and a community of families with a shared commitment to an education that meets the unique needs of each child.

One year later, the children are thriving and the Lantern has become a part of Earth Arts (a well-established local program offering nature-based mentoring programs that connect children and adults to a deeper sense of self, community, and the natural world). Thanks to the Lantern’s sliding scale tuition, the program serves children of varied economic means.

The Lantern: Where Every Child’s Unique Needs Are Met

Housed in an historic one-room schoolhouse, the Lantern follows a Waldorf-inspired curriculum, moving the children through a predictable daily rhythm that includes academics (Math, language arts, social studies, science) and handwork, music, art and yoga.

Small class size is just one way that children receive education focused on their unique needs. The Lantern keeps the class to 15 students with two teachers.

When focusing on core academics, our mixed age group (5-8 year olds) is broken down in smaller skill-based learning groups. Students are presented with skill-appropriate materials and can learn and excel at their own pace.

The campus includes open play space, nature trails, and outdoor classrooms. Outside time is emphasized for both play and learning through cooperative and active games. Moveable school desks and chalkboards allow teachers and students to move their lessons outside.

We need your help to keep the Lantern strong

Our school community has pulled together to make the first year a reality. Parents have hired New York State certified teachers, built the website, scrubbed and cleaned the school, bought supplies, and planned local fundraisers.

Thanks to our sliding scale tuition, more families have been able to attend than would have been otherwise. But to keep the school strong, we need your financial support.

Here’s how your dollars will help the school:

Keeping tuition affordable

Purchasing quality materials for the classroom to maintain the natural and environmental goals of the school

Providing scholarships for families who can’t afford the sliding scale tuition in order to expand the opportunity of nature-based education to families with a greater financial need

Ensuring a future for the school to continue with its excellent educational opportunities

Donations in any amount help! Please consider donating now. You can also help by sharing our fundraiser with your friends and family on social media.

story:
Short Summary

Do your eyes well up with tears when you hear of kids being hurt or abused? Mine too. We can help brighten their life and their holiday with a simple action.

My name is Jake Petruska and I work for Gwendolyn's Cafe in Fort Myers Florida. Each year before the holidays, we start a toy drive to give toys to kids who are housed in the abuse shelter, (ACTABUSE) (actabuse.com), so they can have a great Christmas too.

What We Need:

Gifts:

  • Next time you go shopping, buy an extra gift for one of the ACT kids.
  • Request the Name, age and gender of a child to buy for.
  • Drop it off or ship to the Cafe: 2400 First St., Ste. 101, Ft. Myers FL 33901
  • You can give cash for us to buy gifts with. If we don't hit our goal, all the money still goes to buy gifts for the ACT kids.
  • Bring goodies for the kids like cookies and candy! (non-preishable)

The Impact

True Story:

  • I was talking to my friend the other day and he told me that when he was a kid, he was in the ACT shelter with his mom. He said it was the first good Christmas he remembers. He is 35 today. He still remembers.

Risks & Challenges

  • This is our 2nd annual event
  • We work closely with ACT ABUSE Shelter for accountability
  • We host a holiday party on December 18th where the ACT kids
    and their moms are the guests of honor
  • Santa comes to celebrate with them and give out the gifts

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can't give this year, share our campaign with others on Facebook and social media. Make some noise for us! 
Thank you!

story:
Our Team

The Husky Men's Lacrosse Club at the University of Washington competes in the Men's Collegiate Lacrosse Association (a governing body like the NCAA), that operates over 215 collegiate club lacrosse teams in two divisions. We were founded in 1973 and have seen great on-field successes, including numerous bearths to the post-season and one National Championship.  

Our Need

  • Being a Club Sport, we receive only a small amount of support from the Club Sports Office, about $3000 annually. However, to support a team of 30+ players, conference travel, league and administrative fees, we operate a budget around $80k annually.
  • We do considerable fundraising and seek to minimize costs, however, players still pay the bulk of these bill out of pocket, at $3000 per player annually.
  • Players can lower individual dues through fundraising, however, for some, the deficit between fundraising and dues still presents a burden that prevents talented players from playing.

The Goal

We want to allow those players who are devoted to the team and willing to put in the hard work, the opportunity to play the sport they love. Your donations will directly go to providing this opportunity to those players: 

  • We are raising money to support a need-based scholarship fund that would allow us to make ends meet for player who make the team, but for whom dues are preventing them from playing. 
  • We would like to offer as many scholarships are we are able to, this season we would like to award $500-1500 scholarships to players, based on need. 
  • If we exceed our goal of $5000, we will (1) increase the number of scholarships and (2) save the additional funds raised for scholarships next season!
  • While there are donation perks provided on the right column here, we welcome any donation amounts!
Thank you all so much!

Other Ways You Can Help

Donating might just not be in the cards for you right now, but you can still help us! 

  • Share this campaign! On Facebook, Twitter, where-ever!

Thank you all so much for taking the time to stop by and hope you will support this Scholarship campaign.

story:
The Body Talk Project has been organizing community dance/performance workshops for years. One of the most amazing aspects is that the event organizers for this incredible week of workshops and performance are a group of teens (ages 14-18) called The Cru. They take the lead in choosing the artist facilitators and working together as a team to bring this Spring Break event to life. The Body Talk Project is the youth outreach program of Crimson Coast Dance Society.

Our campaign will enable people of all ages to join the organizers and step onto the floor to learn a fusion of vintage swing/clown/mime/hip hop dance. Everyone can dance and we want to make it easy for all ages and abilities to participate in a fun, creative, inclusive dance environment that gets people active and moving together. Funds raised will help subsidize the workshop fees so that no one will be turned away for lack of funds and so that the teen council, The Cru, are able to complete their learning mentorships for 2014.

Everyone deserves the opportunity to step into a dance studio, experience the skill of professional dance instructors and choreographers and express themselves through the joy of movement. While the Body Talk Cru (the teen organizers) work hard to reduce barriers to participation for their workshop, your financial contribution will help them to be able to offer bursaries for those who are dancing in hard times. Your support will open the studio doors to everyone.  Then the Cru are able to wrap up the project with mentorships in budget reviews, curation, event completion and leadership.

What We Need & What You Get

Whatever funds we raise will go directly to supporting the Body Talk Project Cru component and to enabling community members to participate in the workshops and performance.

•PERKS!!
Check them out!

For Donations after March 22, the same perks apply for Body Talk 2015 OR for our next CCDS production if you are local!  You choose the workshops or performances you see!

Whatever fund we raise will go directly to supporting the Body Talk Project and to enabling community members to participate in the workshops and performance.

The Impact of participation is a strong sense of accomplishment for our youth cru who organized the event and for those community participants who moved out of their comfort zone to attend and perform. Our entire community benefits through a shared experience of mutual support, focused attention toward an artistic performance and the development of new bonds through an investment in joyful expression together.

Expression through movement is our birthright. The Body Talk Project offers teens the opportunity to shine as community organizers and leaders in promoting arts and culture. It also offers people of all ages the chance to step into a dance studio and receive the benefit of supportive, inclusive instruction by renown artists and choreographers. The Body Talk Project creates a world where everyone belongs, everyone can dance, everyone can be who they are and everyone take their place on the stage. With your support, we are making the world a more creative, inclusive and welcoming place for all ages to be engaged citizens, on the dance floor and off.

Crimson Coast Dance Society has produced 100's of events in Nanaimo and are considered a model in community outreach and contribution by the Provincial Arts Council. This is the one project that engages teens and gives them a voice. It has taken place for 7 years now and is held close to the teens heart as a place where their voice is heard. Our strongest vote of approval is the return rate of the teens and families each year and the increased awareness and new faces participating.

If you are unable to contribute money, there are other real ways you can help this campaign.  Please comment, like and share on Facebook.  Please direct others to this campaign via email.  Spread the project by word of mouth, and let people with kids or who love to dance that this only happens once a year, and that this is their chance to join a wonderful professional dance project.  

Please use Indiegogo share tools!

workshops for years. One of the most amazing aspects is that the
event organizers for this incredible week of workshops and
performance are a group of teens (ages 14-18) called The Cru. They take the lead in
choosing the artist facilitators and working together as a team to
bring this Spring Break event to life. The Body Talk Project is the youth outreach
program of Crimson Coast Dance Society.


Our
campaign will enable people of all ages to join the organizers and step onto the floor to
learn a fusion of vintage swing/clown/mime/hip hop dance. Everyone
can dance and we want to make it easy for all ages and abilities to
participate in a fun, creative, inclusive dance environment that gets
people active and moving together. Funds raised will help subsidize
the workshop fees so that no one will be turned away for lack of
funds and so that the teen council, The Cru, are able to complete their learning mentorships for 2014.Everyone
deserves the opportunity to step into a dance studio, experience the
skill of professional dance instructors and choreographers and
express themselves through the joy of movement. While the Body Talk
Cru (the teen organizers) work hard to reduce barriers to
participation for their workshop,  your financial contribution will help them to be
able to offer bursaries for those who are dancing in hard times. Your
support will open the studio doors to everyone.  Then the Cru are able to wrap up the project with mentorships in budget reviews, curation, event completion and leadership.

What
We Need & What You Get


Whatever funds we raise will go directly to supporting the Body Talk Project Cru component and to enabling community members to participate in the workshops and performance.


•PERKS!!Check them out!For Donations after March 22, the same perks apply for Body Talk 2015 OR for our next CCDS production if you are local!  You choose the workshops or performances you see!

Whatever
fund we raise will go directly to supporting the Body Talk Project
and to enabling community members to participate in the workshops and
performance.

The
Impact of participation is a strong sense of accomplishment for our
youth cru who organized the event and for those community
participants who moved out of their comfort zone to attend and
perform.  Our entire community benefits through a shared experience
of mutual support, focused attention toward an artistic performance
and the development of new bonds through an investment in joyful
expression together.



Expression
through movement is our birthright. The Body Talk Project offers
teens the opportunity to shine as community organizers and leaders in
promoting arts and culture. It also offers people of all ages the
chance to step into a dance studio and receive the benefit of
supportive, inclusive instruction by renown artists and
choreographers. The Body Talk Project creates a world where everyone
belongs, everyone can dance, everyone can be who they are and
everyone take their place on the stage. With your support, we are
making the world a more creative, inclusive and welcoming place for
all ages to be engaged citizens, on the dance floor and off.  


Crimson
Coast Dance Society has produced 100's of events in Nanaimo and are
considered a model in community outreach and contribution by the
Provincial Arts Council.  This is the one project that engages teens
and gives them a voice.  It has taken place for 7 years now and is
held close to the teens heart as a place where their voice is heard. 
Our strongest vote of approval is the return rate of the teens and
families each year and the increased awareness and new faces
participating.
If
you are unable to contribute money, there are other real ways you can
help this campaign.  Please comment, like and share on
Facebook.  Please direct others to this campaign via email. 
Spread the project by word of mouth, and let people with kids or who
love to dance that this only happens once a year, and that this is
their chance to join a wonderful professional dance project.  
Please
use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
T  S  C 

Time Space Continuum

What?

Our goal is to buy a school bus, empty it out and use it as a creative space for curating our work. This is an alternative hub for our community to collaborate and deepen common interests. Although the primary focus for the content of the artwork will be film screenings, we will strongly encourage work from all different mediums. We will strive to make the bus into a mobile gallery and drive it to more remote places of the community; the aim is for students to pursue their creative interests by traveling within Providence and local areas. We believe that there is a pure novelty of driving around with friends and acquaintances, slowly and carefully while interacting with art and sharing ideas.

Who?

At the moment our team has a wide spectrum of skills, especially oriented towards media, interactive and video art. Everyone in the group has had extensive creative experience in their field of work and those experiences have contributed to a level of excellence in quality and content.

Where?

Although the main location for the purpose of our project will be within the perimeter of the RISD campus, we are hoping to branch out to neighboring places such as the Walden Pond, Newport, Jamestown and such. 

Funds

As hopeful as we are that this first campaign will succeed, we are aware that this project requires a substantial amount of money. Our alternative is to create a second funding project in order to buy a suitable bus.

Breakdown:

We have the bus. It is a 1994 International DT 408 School Bus. We need to pay for the bus, as well as batteries, gas money and any renovation costs. 


We really appreciate any kind of help you are willing to give us. We are all very excited about this project and we know that it will be an incredible experience from start to finish. We are so grateful for the community that we find ourselves in, it is full of artists and creators and if we succeed in getting this bus we will all be able to share our thoughts and goals in a completely new way. We hope that many people will benefit from this project, and we are extremely excited to go through with it all. Again, thank you so much for your time and support! We are endlessly thankful.

story:
Summary

Common Fare is an idea that was conceived by Chef David Jacobs as a way to marry culture and cuisine. At each of these events, participants get to enjoy a presentation from a local artist, musician, film-maker, photographer, writer, poet, or community activist. The concept behind Common Fare is to create a relaxed environment in which people can interact with emerging personalities in the arts and the community while taking pleasure in excellent food prepared to the highest standards of fine dining...without the pretense. Members and invited guests get the opportunity to remain at the forefront of culture and the arts as well as expand their palettes into new realms of culinary delight. Since its inception, Common Fare has seen resounding success. However, because of the size and limitations of our current venue, our events have been restricted to a select group of 16 individuals. This has also made our events more exclusive than we originally intended. The intimate scale has made the events a lot of fun, but has also kept the cost of attendance high. Through this campaign we hope to obtain a larger venue, opening these events to a much larger audience, and returning to the egalitarian vision in which Common Fare was conceived.


About the Chef

  • For those who know food, cooking is not a job, it's a love affair. Having been involved in restaurants and catering for over 20 years, that magic has not waned for Chef David Jacobs...he still finds himself hypnotized by the beauty and magic of food. 

    Originally intending to pursue a career in academia, Chef David worked, like many students, in restaurants, bars, and catering during his school years. By fate or chance, he found himself under the tutelage of several great chefs and eventually decided to work at what he adores, working his way up through the ranks in kitchens around the city, the country, and the world. Along the way he became a personal trainer and certified sports nutritionist which has greatly influenced his cooking. Chef David has developed a focus on health-supportive cooking prepared to the highest standards of fine-dining preparation and presentation.

story:
Update 7/20/12

We are rapidly nearing the end of our campaign, and we are about 1/4 of the way to our goal. Artists for World Peace would like to thank everyone who has generously given their time and money to help support our cause.

However, our children still need your help!

All contributed funds go directly to fund the education of these amazing children from Kibosho, Tanzania. Please, help keep them in school!

 

 

Campaign Info

Artists for World Peace began the Children of Peace project as a way to support orphans and underprivileged children around the world. Right now, the children of the Good Hope Trust Orphanage need your help. Josephine, director of Good Hope Trust, was concerned about how to best meet the needs of the kids as they became adolescents. She decided that sending them to private boarding school, a usual practice for quality education in Tanzania, would offer them the best chance for educational success.

 

Artists for World Peace now helps support and educate nine of the children from the orphanage, paying private tuition of $1,000 a year for eight of the children. Our youngest child is only two years old and is not yet in school.

 

All contributed funds go directly to our children in Tanzania. In addition to financial help, you can also share our story with your circles of friends. We greatly appreciate any support!

 

 

Artists for World Peace is a nonprofit foundation located in Middletown, Connecticut. Since 2003, we have created opportunities for artists to work for social justice and raise funds to benefit humanitarian causes locally and internationally.

 

All donations are tax deductible. To find out more about us, please visit www.artistsforworldpeace.org, or check us out on Facebook at Artists for World Peace.

story:
Welcome to my project!!! Who I am: My name is Vicky Pierce and I am an Infant Developmental Specialist with over 20 years of experience providing early intervention therapies to young children and their families. What I do: My special expertise is in helping families learn and use positive parenting techniques with their children. However, I find myself sounding like a broken record (remember those?!), repeating this same information in most every house that I go to, month after month and year after year.

So, I'm creating an awesome new app that will grab a much wider audience and help me spread the good parenting word in order to make the world a happier, more peaceful place. How it works: The focus of the Tantrum911! app is on positive reinforcement of "good" behavior, while helping parents feel competent in reducing the frequency and duration of “bad” behavior. Tantrum911! will be free for the basics and there will be three In-App purchases for 99 cents each.

I call the first one Planes, Trains and Automobiles. This will address special behavior challenges such as those encountered in a hot car in the first 5 minutes of a 3 day road trip, on a nice long flight to India or an extended overnight ride on the EuroStar.

The second one is a handy, dandy timer to keep track of those time-out minutes. The 3rd In-App purchase will be a “Reward” – A reward page for children to use when they are behaving well. Perhaps I'll add a reward page for their parents who, let's face it, are trying their best to behave well in the face of toddler adversity!

Why it works: Because I really do know what I'm doing and lets face it, we could all use a lot less screaming and kicking from the children in our world! Just think how nice that next airplane trip will be without a screaming toddler kicking the back of your already-cramped, over-priced Coach seat, causing you to spill your adult beverage right when the pilots have just turned on the Fasten Seat Belt sign.

Trust me, you want this app to fly!! Seriously, Tantrum911! is on the cutting-edge of a relatively untapped niche in the app market. I teach these menthods every day and they work. Every single parent with a toddler can benefit from this app, and there is nothing else like it available. The money you donate will be used exclusively for developing and marketing the app so that ALL families can access its positive parenting message and we can all live happily ever after. It will be made available in English and Spanish and other languages as the entire world eventually catches on.

story:
CampInteractive : Teach. Build. Inspire.

supported by Nokia

We need your help to change the lives of 25 inner-city youth by sending them to CampInteractive's Summer Tech Camp.  

It costs $850 to put each student through the program.  Your support will fund scholorships for 25 amazing NYC kids.

---

In support of the campaign Nokia has generously agreed to  match every dollar you donate up to $10,000! By donating to this campaign, you help to double the impact.

---

Who are we?

CampInteractive (CI) is a Bronx-based nonprofit that inspires underprivileged inner-city youth through the creative power of technology.  

At CI, students are transitioned from consumers of media to creative and critically thinking producers. Through learning coding, photography, videography, website building, and blogging, students are able to cultivate a voice that will be heard and seen through various channels.  These skills are then used to document their personal journey in exciting outdoor adventures such as: surfing, hiking, rock climbing, snowboarding, sailing, camping, and more.

At the conclusion of this intensive program, CI students are given the opportunity to intern at top NYC technology companies -- giving them the real-world experience that will ensure success.

Who do we serve?

CI operates in one of New York City’s poorest neighborhoods where the income and education quality are at their worst. In our community:

  • 40% of households live below the Poverty Line
  • 25% of households subsist on less than $10,000 annually
  • The average student to teacher ratio is 35:1

Why CampInteractive?

Did you know that:

  • Less than 60% of minorities have access to the internet due digital divide
  • Less than 12% of Bachelors Degrees in Computer Sciences are earned by minorities

We know these stats. We firmly believe that teaching hard skills in web development, IT, quality assurance, and creative technology disciplines to this demographic is the best way to break the cycle of poverty. 

We also understand that students need more than skills to succeed, they also need the courage to use their abilities.  

Our year round programs support, educuate and inspire kids to view the world as a limitless pool of possibility.

 

Learn More!

website - tumblr - twitter - facebook - volunteer

 

Check out this great infographic on the digital divide!

story:
Our Story

Students Active For Ending Rape (SAFER) began in 2000 as a group of students at Columbia University who led the campus in a grassroots campaign to reform the school’s sexual assault policy. More than ten years later, SAFER is a national nonprofit organization that empowers students across the country to change how their colleges prevent and respond to sexual assault. A volunteer-led organization, SAFER facilitates student organizing through a comprehensive training manual (PDF); in-person workshops and trainings; free follow-up mentoring; our SAFER/V-Day Campus Accountability Project Database; and a growing online resource library for student organizers.

Visit our website to read more about SAFER and its history.


Why SAFER?

  • We are the only organization that fights sexual violence and rape culture by empowering student-led campaigns to reform college sexual assault policies.
  • We recognize how sexual assault is connected to all forms of individual and institutional oppression including racism, sexism, and homo/transphobia.
  • We create leaders by training students in effective organizing tactics
  • We teach students how to build inclusive movements that involve people of identities that vary (for example: gender, race, ability, sexual orientation, nationality, and ethnicity) so everyone’s voice is heard.

POLICY, POLICY, POLICY

We believe that a good policy is the key to a strong anti-sexual violence program on campus. Today, most colleges and universities have dangerously inadequate policies with procedures that can leave victims feeling retraumatized, deny students due process, and ignore disparate treatment of survivors and assailants based on gender, class, race, sexual orientation, and disability. By keeping these inadequate policies, colleges are allowing an atmosphere that condones violence, silences survivors, and reduces equal access to the benefits of a college education

Want to learn more about policy? Visit our website to learn more about what makes a comprehensive sexual assault policy. You can also view our Youtube video about why policy is important to an anti-violence movement.

The Impact

Sexual violence is the number one violent crime on college campuses.  The Department of Justice found that at least 1 in 4 women are survivors of campus sexual violence. This important issue has been getting a lot more attention recently with an investigation by the Center for Public Integrity, an award-winning series by NPR, the latest Dear Colleague Letter regarding Title IX from the Office for Civil Rights, and coverage of the impact of campus sexual assault in  Cosmopolitan magazine.


With the increased visibility of the issue, more students are seeking our services. Demand for our trainings has grown over 200% in the past two years and we need your help to increase our capacity and meet that need.

 

What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we can raise $7,000. By helping us expand our capacity, your donation will help pay for:

  • mentors that provide FREE one-on-one guidance to student activists;
  • bringing trainers to the schools of student activists across the country;
  • educating college staff and students about the unique dynamics of sexual assault on college campuses;
  • allowing student groups of ANY budget to bring SAFER to campus.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about our campaign!
  • Join our email list to stay up to date on what’s happening with us
  • Follow us on Twitter, Tumblr, and Facebook!

story:
Our Story

The Hout Bay United Football Community (HBUFC) is a non-profit football club created to unify the racially and economically divided community of Hout Bay, a seaside suburb of Cape Town, South Africa.

Its mission is to unite, uplift & support the community of Hout Bay through the beautiful game of soccer. Kids receive the highest quality coaching free of charge and play games throughout the year. By continuing to provide logistics, organisation, management and coaching for the players, our hope is to foster and mentor talent from every corner of Hout Bay, making it possible for kids to reach for their dreams on the field and in everyday life.

We are more than a charity, we are an ambitious, competitive and highly spirited organization where the elite players, the idols and mentors within the communities, have fought their way up to the top of the 2nd division and have their sites firmly set on leveling up to the National First Division (NFD) and then the PSL, South Africa’s Premier Soccer League.

What We Do:

We Uplift:

All three communities in Hout Bay receive the highest quality professional coaching, free of charge, exposing them to a structured, disciplined and focused environment that provides life skills and guidance.

*The skills given to kids at HBUFC translate off the field; teachers have described the kids who attend HBUFC as well-mannered and disciplined, while statistically, the kids from HBUFC also perform better at school.

We Unite:

Emphasis is given to cross-community integration. Each team is made up of players from the three divided communities that make up the greater Hout Bay community.

We Support:

Players receive employment at HBUFC as coaches and mentors. The professional players at the elite level receive a salary each month.  Currently, 100% of our Elite squad that are not studying are in full-time employment. Our disciplined environment shows players what can be achieved with hard work & dedication and gives them hope to achieve their dreams.

Fundraising objective:

“Raise money, Raise the team, Raise the community”.

Our objective is to expand on the work we do within the community. To continue to unite and uplift while setting an example and creating a model for the rest of the country to follow. It costs R45 000 a year to keep an Elite player on the field, and enable them to continue to do the work they do within the community as mentors and coaches.

Your donation will have far reaching benefits both on and off the field, it will:

On the field:

• Pay for the Elite players to receive top quality coaching.

• Their kit and equipment.

• Keep them playing and employed at HBUFC so that they can…

Off the field:

• Continue their work as coaches and mentors to the junior teams, ensuring that the kids receive the highest quality professional coaching free of charge.

• Expose these kids to a disciplined and focused environment*.

• Continue to assist kids with their reading classes.

 
 

Meet a few of the people whose lives you’ll be changing:

Gabriel ‘Gabba’ Warner

Gabriel is an extremely gifted footballer who came to the club with no professional training. He's currently our first-choice keeper, with lightning quick reactions and a cool calm attitude that means he always up for the big occasion.

Your donation will not only enable him to continue to play professionally for our Elite team, but will also ensure that he remains able to provide free coaching to the kids in the community and assist them with their reading via the classes he holds.

Mzwandile ‘Zwai’ Ntozini

Zwai is the club’s talismanic centre forward. Our leading scorer he has played for the club since our very first semi-professional game.  His calm, soft demeanour has also made him one of our best coaches. As such, he helps run our after-school program and coaches the HBUFC U14 boy’s & girl’s teams. 

Your donation will not only keep Zwai playing for HBUFC, but also allow him to provide guidance to kids from the community both on the field and off.

Dillon ‘Zlatan’ Lakay

Zlatan is an extremely talented winger. Strong and athletic, he’s great in the air and always dangerous when shooting. Zlatan scores outrageous goals and is responsible for an absolute screamer of a free kick in our debut season that helped us seal victory in a must-win game to avoid relegation.

Your support for Dillon will allow him to continue to play for HBUFC, coach the HBUFC U12 team and provide mentorship in our after-school program*.

* Statistically, the kids from HBUFC perform better at school, with teachers described the kids who attend HBUFC as well-mannered and disciplined.
story_txt: Our Story The Hout Bay United Football Community (HBUFC) is a non-profit football club created to unify the racially and economically divided community of Hout Bay, a seaside suburb of Cape Town, South Africa.Its mission is to unite, uplift & support the community of Hout Bay through the beautiful game of soccer. Kids receive the highest quality coaching free of charge and play games throughout the year. By continuing to provide logistics, organisation, management and coaching for the players, our hope is to foster and mentor talent from every corner of Hout Bay, making it possible for kids to reach for their dreams on the field and in everyday life.We are more than a charity, we are an ambitious, competitive and highly spirited organization where the elite players, the idols and mentors within the communities, have fought their way up to the top of the 2nd division and have their sites firmly set on leveling up to the National First Division (NFD) and then the PSL, South Africa’s Premier Soccer League.What We Do:We Uplift:All three communities in Hout Bay receive the highest quality professional coaching, free of charge, exposing them to a structured, disciplined and focused environment that provides life skills and guidance.*The skills given to kids at HBUFC translate off the field; teachers have described the kids who attend HBUFC as well-mannered and disciplined, while statistically, the kids from HBUFC also perform better at school.We Unite:Emphasis is given to cross-community integration. Each team is made up of players from the three divided communities that make up the greater Hout Bay community.We Support:Players receive employment at HBUFC as coaches and mentors. The professional players at the elite level receive a salary each month.  Currently, 100% of our Elite squad that are not studying are in full-time employment. Our disciplined environment shows players what can be achieved with hard work & dedication and gives them hope to achieve their dreams.Fundraising objective:“Raise money, Raise the team, Raise the community”.Our objective is to expand on the work we do within the community. To continue to unite and uplift while setting an example and creating a model for the rest of the country to follow. It costs R45 000 a year to keep an Elite player on the field, and enable them to continue to do the work they do within the community as mentors and coaches.Your donation will have far reaching benefits both on and off the field, it will:On the field:• Pay for the Elite players to receive top quality coaching.• Their kit and equipment.• Keep them playing and employed at HBUFC so that they can…Off the field:• Continue their work as coaches and mentors to the junior teams, ensuring that the kids receive the highest quality professional coaching free of charge.• Expose these kids to a disciplined and focused environment*.• Continue to assist kids with their reading classes.  Meet a few of the people whose lives you’ll be changing:Gabriel ‘Gabba’ WarnerGabriel is an extremely gifted footballer who came to the club with no professional training. He's currently our first-choice keeper, with lightning quick reactions and a cool calm attitude that means he always up for the big occasion.Your donation will not only enable him to continue to play professionally for our Elite team, but will also ensure that he remains able to provide free coaching to the kids in the community and assist them with their reading via the classes he holds.Mzwandile ‘Zwai’ NtoziniZwai is the club’s talismanic centre forward. Our leading scorer he has played for the club since our very first semi-professional game.  His calm, soft demeanour has also made him one of our best coaches. As such, he helps run our after-school program and coaches the HBUFC U14 boy’s & girl’s teams. Your donation will not only keep Zwai playing for HBUFC, but also allow him to provide guidance to kids from the community both on the field and off.Dillon ‘Zlatan’ LakayZlatan is an extremely talented winger. Strong and athletic, he’s great in the air and always dangerous when shooting. Zlatan scores outrageous goals and is responsible for an absolute screamer of a free kick in our debut season that helped us seal victory in a must-win game to avoid relegation.Your support for Dillon will allow him to continue to play for HBUFC, coach the HBUFC U12 team and provide mentorship in our after-school program*.* Statistically, the kids from HBUFC perform better at school, with teachers described the kids who attend HBUFC as well-mannered and disciplined.

story:
We want to inspire children to read multicultural books. We do this through our adorable and relatable characters Suno, Dekho Jaano and our age-appropriate stories that allow children to experience our beautiful Indian culture. Our popular books are fun and authentic while being mainstream, which appeals to kids, parents, and educators of all ethnicities and backgrounds. 



In return of your generous contribution, you can choose from a host of rewards based on your pledge including: free shipping, EARLY BIRD SPECIAL OFFERS, signed copies of both the Paratha and Diwali books or even translating the book to the language of your choice. 






The Mystery of the missing parathas takes kids through a fun food adventure. It's a story that will make them wear detective hats as they hunt for the parathas ( Indian flat bread) that suddenly go missing right before Suno’s Dadima’s (grandma) going away party.

Here is a sneak peak of the book:






This page turner will not only make you wonder who stole the parathas but will let you experience the sights and smells found in an Indian home along the way. It is sure to make the pickiest of eaters want to try some parathas or even cook them!

BEHIND THE SCENES 

Wondering how Suno, Dekho and Jaano were created? Check out our talented illustrator Nadia Ronquillo bring these monkeys to life!




In the past, we have had great success with our award winning and popular Indian book, The Diwali Gift and our Dress Up Party App. Our books was sold out across the country and we received great response from parents, grandparents, teachers and more importantly kids! 

We now can’t wait to bring this mouthwatering adventure story to our young readers!

BACKERS TESTIMONY


Our research showed that even though schools and communities have become a melting pot of cultures, we as parents and educators do not have the tools to share Indian culture with young kids.


Currently, only 10% of mainstream children’s media such as TV, books and Apps have any characters of color. Out of these, there are none that depicts South Asians in positive and prominent roles. So where are those fun books? We surely could not find them in bookstores and libraries. 

We urgently need more avenues for the next generation of kids to validate their cultural roots.

We want to change the way the world views Indians and break away from current stereotypes.That is why we're making beautifully illustrated hardback books for kids. 

We write our stories in a way such that kids can relate to the characters and become curious about Indian culture while having fun. For educators, we offer great kid-oriented content which can be easily shared in their multicultural classrooms.


The 3 Curious Monkeys; Suno, Dekho, and Jaano get little readers interested in the story and help them absorb the cultural references more deeply while encouraging them to respond with curiosity.  All are characters ( 1 girl and 2 boy monkeys) are equally involved in being funny, silly, kind, smart, confident, and adventurous thus breaking any gender stereotypes.


Here's a quick look at how we'll be spending the money and our timeline for completing the project.

We’re Shuchi and Shweta, the co-founders of 3 Curious Monkeys. We have been friends for over a decade, and for the past 2 years, we have been trying to revolutionize the way Indian culture is portrayed in young children’s media.

This journey started when we both become moms. As Indian American parents raising our kids in our multicultural communities, we struggled to find ways to connect our kids to our Indian culture which we both hold so dearly to our hearts. 

Kids especially those between the ages of 2-7 years are impressionable and vulnerable. We noticed that our kids started to identify themselves as being ‘different’ and on many occasions wanted to change the color of their skin, or were ashamed of taking Indian food for their school lunches and were not as excited about celebrating Indian holidays.


We surveyed other parents who were part of blended families and even educators to learn that these issues of low self-esteem were more common than we had imagined and unfortunately everyone was struggling to find a solution.

That’s when we decided to leave our corporate jobs and use our combined experience of over 20 years in retail, business development, marketing and sales to create Indian characters who would share authentic yet contemporary stories about Indian culture to young kids.

Why is this project so important to us?

Because Indian culture is absolutely amazing and as parents, it should be easy for us to make our kids equally excited about it!

We’re on Indiegogo because we want to make sure that children get to experience Indian culture in the most authentic and relatable manner so they don’t grow up to be confused or embarrassed about their cultural identities. We want them to be able to share their culture with their friends and bond over similarities while celebrating differences.

With your support, we believe we can help our next generation of kids to grow up to be well-informed and tolerant global citizens.

Help us preserve Indian Culture through children's books!

Risks and challenges

We already had a successful book and an App in the market so we know how to bring quality products to our customers. But above all, we have a network of trustworthy, talented artists and designers we have been working closely with for the past 2 years to minimize the risks involved.

To further minimize risks, we started working on this project one year ago, researching Indian stories that kids, getting feedback from parents and teachers and even our young readers before we decided on the style and look of "The Mystery of the missing parathas"

We’re working with Nadia Ronquillo, a talented illustrator with heaps of experience, so we know the book is going to look amazing.

To meet our fast approaching deadlines, we have printers on standby to receive our order and ship them to us ASAP

We’ve given ourselves plenty of time to send out the books and fulfill the other rewards by Diwali ( October) 2016.

We now need your support to get our books in the hands of all our little readers.

Thank you so much for your support!
