story:
MONSTER MATH – DISCOVER THE MATH IN YOU


FROM K -12

Everyone has an equal chance of winning.  Each player starts by selecting their grade level.  The game will then pose questions which test the basic mathematical principles and skill sets required for that grade, from K through 12.


WHAT YOU ARE HELPING TO CREATE

  Monster Math is a digital game with a focus on improving math skills by making the experience fun. It also diagnoses the stumbling blocks facing the players, providing the parents or teachers with valuable information to assist in the players' learning.

  Created alongside teachers and thoroughly tested in the classroom, the game allows players of varying ages and skill levels to compete on a levelled playing field.  Each player selects their own grade, the game then poses questions which test the basic mathematical principles and skill sets. Everyone, from K - 12, has an equal chance of winning as Players take turns answering at their level, collecting tokens for correct answers. 

  Playing Monster Math for one hour per week, during the school year, ensures each player covers the entire syllabus of an academic year.  The practise contributes to a smoother academic journey and Monster Math can identify a concept that may have not been completely understood.  Even if your child or student has only 10 minutes to spare each day, they can play our math game and get results.

  Monster Math has multiple modes: games will be pass-and-play, with all the players using the same device; or asynchronous over the Internet, with each player using their own device and taking their turn when the app notifies them. The game is stored in the cloud, allowing players to play and pause whenever they like on their tablet, smartphone, computer or laptop.

System features:

  • Questions professionally prepared and tested.
  • Every answer is analysed for exactly which basic principles has stumped the player, highlighting exactly where these shortfalls exist.
  • Empowers teachers, parents and students to focus on the root of a deficiency in understanding.
  • Organised according to the school syllabus.
  • Leveled according to each player's age/school grade.
  • High quality graphics and user interface.
  • Can be played throughout a student's school career.
  • Questions simple enough for a player who understands the basic math principle to answer quickly, while not obvious enough for a player who does not understand the principle to guess correctly.
  • Players can choose to play with a set of questions relevant to a previous year's syllabus until they have reached the skill level of their current academic year, reinforcing learning.
  • Parents can choose a set of questions which are relevant to their own level of education or memory of mathematics concepts.  Parents can even select the same grade set of questions as their child is currently answering.
  • With all grade level questions available, a family can enjoy the game for years - an educational pastime which progresses as children progress through school.


WHAT IS MONSTER MATH

Monster Math is an edu-game which keeps track of every question in every game, analysing exactly which basic principles are stumping each player. Many children, and adults, develop a mental barrier towards mathematics.  This is most often the result of having, at some stage, missed or misunderstood a basic foundational concept.


WHAT YOU GET FOR SUPPORTING US

  The rewards are listed for your level of contribution to the right.  The most valuable being, the "Einstein" reward tier, at $99 for a lifetime family membership.

  Beyond this, all "Limited" reward tiers will be eligible for discounts on LinkedUpLearning's future math education products.

  You could also take this opportunity to become a sponsor!  Businesses and other organisations can become patrons of their staffs' families, their local school, or even utilise these memberships in a marketing campaign to their customers.

  Each subscription gives access to sets of questions for all grades (K-12), covering all of the core math skill sets for each year.  Subscribers have all the math content they need for an entire school career.  If a skillset is misunderstood or missed, a player can go back to a lower grade to reinforce the misunderstood skill, as they have all previous grade's syllabi included.

The "12 Friends" included in all of the reward tiers allows a Member to invite up to 12 friends to join in and play the game. These are not full member accounts, so friends can only join a game when invited by someone with a full Monster Math account.

Note: When the game is released commercially, each grade will be sold individually. The total for all of the grade question sets from K-12 will be around $420.


WHY CONTRIBUTE?

  You enable the conversion of Rod's original board game to digital technology.  This allows the Monster Math edu-game to make mathematics fun and help thousands of children, around the world, gain access to an important tool which can evaluate their grasp of math fundamentals.

  We believe we can have a product available for our backers by January 2014 after the successful campaign.

WHERE THE FUNDS ARE GOING


WHO WE ARE AND THE GAME'S HISTORY

  My name is Rod Cummings and I am Founder of LinkedUpLearning. From an early age I was passionate about mathematics; but soon discovered that not everyone enjoyed it. I found myself teaching my fellow students who struggled with their math exercises.

  In the 90's I developed a unique way to address the dread of mathematics by developing a system that helped people learn in a fun and progressive manner.  With my systems and programs in place, I began teaching extracurricular maths in labs using computers.

  Eventually, I developed a board game based around a student’s grasp of math fundamentals. By playing the game for just one hour each week, a player would cover the skill sets needed for an entire grade. What gave me even more satisfaction was that it made math fun and allowed players to discover the same love of the subject that I have.

  Ultimately, over 25,000 of these board games were sold to schools, proving effective with outstanding math learning results for its players.

  We also have a team who are dedicated to enhancing education, some holding masters degrees in mathematics and computer science.  All are experienced developers. We studied the physiology and concepts of mathematics, culminating in the development of unique mathematics courseware engines. We have the experience of teaching 3,000+ students and teachers using this mathematics courseware via the Internet, combined with owning and operating mathematical teaching laboratories.  This is LinkedUpLearning, the team behind Monster Math.


YOUR INVOLVEMENT

  As a backer you will receive regular monthly newsletters concerning our progress in the development of Monster Math. 

  We will also invite your input, from time to time, regarding some of the user interface designs.  Your feedback is important to us and will make the final form of the game even better.

  Once Monster Math is released, if you are interested, we will continue to update you on our progress in the development of our online courseware system.  As a backer, we believe that you may have an interest in knowing what we will be doing beyond this campaign. 

Thank you for your interest.  We look forward to your support.


            * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 

LinkedUpLearning.com

5836 Old West Saanich Road, Victoria, BC, V9E 2H1

Email: contact@LinkedUpLearning.com   Tel: +1 (250) 381-6888

story:
Hi, I'm Cale Brighton and I'm trying to raise money to go on a class trip to Washington DC this summer.

I'm 13 years old, and over the last few years, I've become very interested and excited about global studies and our United States government; more specifically, it's role in our everyday lives.

Towards the end of last year, we were presented with an opportunity to sign up for this trip to Washington DC that leaves Des Moines on June 17th. The total amount each of us needs to pay is roughly $1500. My family had managed to come up with around $500 when my dad lost his job. Obviously this was a big setback for my family and my hopes of going on this trip.

Recently, my parents and I have started asking friends and neighbors if they have any housework that I can do in exchange for donations but now that we are just over a month away from the deadline for my trip, we have decided to kick it up a notch and set up a fundraising campaign, and hope that you will find it in your hearts to make a donation so that I might be able to reach my goal and be able to go on this possible once in a lifetime trip.

story:
Beyond the Bell offers a safe alternative for school age students who might otherwise be left at home unsupervised during the day. Our program offers after school services for children from 5 years to 12 years of age. Summer and holiday camps are also available.

Beyond the Bell will serve multiple purposes. Firstly, Beyond the Bell provides an innovative approach to after school care as the founders and owners are both certified Elementary and Special Education school teachers who are able to provide exceptional learning opportunities during the program’s “Bright Hour.” Our program provides enrichment activities that meet the developmental needs and interests of children. In addition, Beyond the Bell will collaborate with schools in order to provide students with supplemental enrichment activities based on the standards in which teachers are focusing.

Implementing Beyond the Bell will have a direct impact that will assist in creating lifelong learners through the following enrichment activities:

  • Educational enrichment opportunities
  • Team building activities
  • Critical thinking advancement
  • Social skill development
  • Community involvement
  • Health and fitness development

Indirectly, the implementation of Beyond the Bell is expected to:

  • Increase homework completion
  • Improve attendance and test scores
  • Decrease behavior difficulties
  • Instill a love of learning and create a sense of belonging
  • Increase health, wellness and fitness
  • Potentially decrease juvenile crime

Beyond the Bell will be a positive and beneficial addition for schools and students. Our program will provide a school-based environment where extended academic and social learning is the norm.  Thank you very much for your time in reading this and Beyond the Bell is looking forward to making a change in the lives of youth across Arizona.


The funding received will help our program acquire the materials needed to provide our students with various enrichment activities in the areas of music, science, technology, mathematics, art/fine art, health, fitness, team building, social skills, language, community and literature. Furthermore, donations will also be used to allow students to participate in field trips and various community activities. For example, Beyond the Bell will contract guest speakers to both educate and entertain our students. Whether or not our monetary goal is reached, the donations contributed will be used to fund the aforementioned activities that will Advance Bright Children.

story:
The Global Leaders Program of DC Bilingual Public Charter School provides 5th grade students with the opportunity to apply what they’ve learned in the classroom to the world around them in a cross-cultural exchange program to Puerto Rico. The 5th Graders’ preparation for this journey begins 12 weeks prior to departure through a series of teambuilding activities and student-led presentations about Puerto Rican history and culture. Overall, the Global Leaders Program seeks to open minds, expand lenses, and cultivate a sense of understanding and accountability to the local and global communities in which we all depend.

Throughout the weeklong excursion, from May 15th to May 21st, students interact with local culture and Spanish language, fulfilling a critical language and cultural immersion component of DC Bilingual’s dual-language curriculum. Some of the activities planned for the students include: meet local students at Escuela Ángela Cordero Bernard and participate in a service-learning project; visit the historic coffee plantation Hacienda Buena Vista; explore the fort, El Morro, on the shores of San Juan; and cruise through the brilliant Phosphorescent Bay. The itinerary for each day is interwoven with both educational moments and fun activities to ensure students get the most out of this unique experience with DC Bilingual.

In order to continue to provide educational opportunities that cultivate leadership skills beyond the classroom, we need your financial support. A DC Bilingual Global Leader sponsorship costs $1500.00 which includes: transportation, accommodation, and meals. Considering many of the families cannot afford this amount, DC Bilingual Global Leaders contribute to their own expenses by organizing school fundraisers which estimate at nearly $5,000 total contribution. There are 28 students interested in the program. Whether you donate $25 or $200, your support is appreciated at any level!

We would like to receive all donations prior to May 14th, 2012.

Your contribution will plant the seeds needed to grow our students into lifelong learners as they continue on to achieve as emerging global leaders.  On behalf of the 2012 graduating 5th grade class, we ask for your support!

story:
The Cause

What are you giving this holiday season? Provide an invaluable gift this year by supporting an impoverished child's future. Contributing to our holiday campaign will help ensure that our students continue to receive a quality education. It is with help from individuals like yourself that we have been able to continue our work for over fifteen years.

Our Story

The Right to Learn is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing the disadvantaged children of Nagarote, Nicaragua with a free, Montessori education. The Right to Learn accomplishes this mission primarily through its funding of School of Louise’s Dreams, where over 130 pre-elementary and elementary students are provided with everything they need to effectively receive a quality education. You can read more about our unique story here.

What We Need & What We Offer

Donations will go directly to the Right to Learn, and will help provide for the education needs of the students in the upcoming academic year, beginning in February. Donations will cover items such as meals, school supplies, transportation, and uniforms. 


Donations of all sizes are welcome. Donations of $25 or more will receive a picture collage and personalized thank you from The Right to Learn. Donations of over $300, whether jointly or individually, qualifies you as a Student Sponsor. Student Sponsors provide the funding necessary for one year of a student's education, and receive profiles and personalized thank yous from their student. You can read more about our Student Sponsorship program here.

Other Ways You Can Help

Check out our "share tools" to spread the word about our campaign through social media!

Our Story


The Right to Learn is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing the disadvantaged children of Nagarote, Nicaragua with a free, Montessori education. The Right to Learn accomplishes this mission primarily through its funding of School of Louise’s Dreams, where over 130 pre-elementary and elementary students are provided with everything they need to effectively receive a quality education. You can read more about our unique story here.


What We Need & What We Offer

Donations will go directly to the Right to Learn, and will help provide for the education needs of the students in the upcoming academic year, beginning in February. Donations will cover items such as meals, school supplies, transportation, and uniforms. 

Donations of all sizes are welcome. Donations of $25 or more will receive a picture collage and personalized thank you from The Right to Learn. Donations of over $300, whether jointly or individually, qualifies you as a Student Sponsor. Student Sponsors provide the funding necessary for one year of a student's education, and receive profiles and personalized thank yous from their student. You can read more about our Student Sponsorship program here.Other Ways You Can Help

Check out our "share tools" to spread the word about our campaign through social media!

story:
The Story

I'm a 24 yr old North Carolina native. Howard University Alumna (Business Admin/Marketing Major). I now currently reside in the big NYC working for advertising agency, Ogilvy & Mather! (big change from the little town in North Carolina, but I'm loving it). I have been very blessed to make it to where I am today. I know that this was only accomplished because of the wonderful people that have surrounded me throughout my life. I realize now it is time I pay it forward.


I've always adored working with children, helping whether it was through coaching little league teams, tutoring, babysitting, or being a mentor in different community programs. Now I'm ready to go bigger and do more! Leaving my comfortable confines of the US to reach out where I can have a large impact.


I have been afforded an amazing opportunity to volunteer with the Shanti Bhavan Children's Project in India. In August, I'm off to a small, rural village in India where I will be teaching intelligent yet underprivileged students! 

I will be in a small village two hours south of Bangalore, for 2.5 months I'll be aiding the Indian teachers and leading my own classes. The students range from age 4 to Seniors in High School. There I will be helping in which ever subjects need my help: math, science, arts/crafts, dance, & possibly some business/economic classes.

The Impact

Shanti Bhavan, also know as "Haven of Peace", is a home and a boarding school to some of the most underprivileged children in India. They are children of the Dalit caste, the "Untouchables".

Shanti provides a space for the children to live, learn and develop using a completely unique and innovative model of combating poverty, educating the poor and fighting social injustice. Admitting students at the age of four, Shanti Bhavan provides a holistic, high quality education until the age of 17 free of cost, and subsequently funds college education for its students.


Without Shanti Bhavan, many of these students may not have ever received an adequate education ...much less the opportunities or options placed in front of them to make a brighter future for themselves, their family and often their community.


Shanti Bhavan's children see that a better world isn’t just an idea but a real possibility. Turning them into adults who will now have the power to contribute to a better world.


To see just how wonderful Shanti Bhavan is and the impact it has had on its community, check out the following links to learn more about this amazing cause:


Covered on ABC Dateline:  http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/

Shanti's Website: www.shantibhavanonline.org


How you can help!

My job has been wonderful enough to grant me a personal leave of absence, but of course the leave is unpaid. Which is what brings me to you asking for your help! While I'm gone from work for the next 3 months I'll be volunteering with no income pouring in! My living expenses will be minimal, but I need your help getting to India and covering all the small expenses that are really adding up.

I've dipped into all my savings to make this trip happen, but still have quite a bit of expenses to cover. Here is a breakdown of where your contributions will help!!

  • Roundtrip flight to Bangalore- $1400
  • Repair laptop - $500 (I will use the laptop to create my lesson plans, skype my worried mother, and keep all of you in the loop via a blog site while I'm gone)
  • Indian Visa -$76
  • Immunizations - $300 (the shots needed aren't covered by my insurance)
  • Health insurance x3 months - $750 (i can keep the insurance provided by my company but i'll have to make the monthly payments while i'm on leave)
  • Teaching supplies for my classes -$100
  • Supplies for kids - whatever you can help me afford!!!! (Clothes, toiletries, school supplies)


Other Ways You Can Help

1) Spread the word! Pass this page on to a friend, family member, coworker.. to strangers too! :-) Email, Facebook, Twitter.. however you can share! The more the merrier!

2) Say a prayer for me! This is a serious responsibility I'm about to take on and affects the children's future so much, I only want to give it my all and do a good job. So wish me luck!

story:
Summary

          Just a couple days ago, it arrived in my email inbox - my invitation to become a Google Glass Explorer.  What an opportunity to open up the doors of my high school English classroom, to connect my tenth grade students with writers, publishers, experts, and other students all over the world.

          I have been fortunate to be able to use Skype and Google Hangouts to connect my classroom with a variety of authors and learn from experts about the writing and publishing process. Using their advice, we use online tools to draft, revise, and submit our work for publication. But we are using technology that is slow and tied to one space in our classroom, making our video connections cumbersome and hard for all students in my class to participate. Adding Google Glass to our classroom will ensure that all of my students have an opportunity to connect with writing experts. Google Glass is a wearable technology that would make it easier for my students to not only participate in video chats but also create their own videos of what they are learning.  Students would more easily be able to connect and produce work for real audiences rather than simply turning in another paper that only the teacher reads. Wearable technology opens up a world of possibilities!

What We Need & What You Get

          Being invited to become a Google Glass Explorer is an honor, but it also comes with a pricetag that is just a bit out of reach.  The cost of this wearable technology is $1500 + shipping and additional costs, so I am asking for $1700 to help cover the cost of this project.

          In return for your support, you will receive a thank you letter from me as well as highlighted on my blog - I Am a Teacher Et Cetera - as a supporter of our classroom and where you will also find reflections and videos on how we are using Glass in our high school English classroom.

The Impact

          When students can talk with experts, with publishers and authors, writing becomes real.  Students are not only more engaged but empowered.  They begin to understand that writing and learning is not just something that happens inside the four walls of our classroom.  Google Glass would open up opportunities for my students to share their learning and their writing with real audiences as well as help my students connect with readers and writers from all over the world.  What an exciting time to be a student!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, it doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please talk with your friends and family about this project to help raise support.
  • Share this project using the links below and help me get the word out!

story:
Greetings Supporters!

I am filled to the brim with excitement about the Holistic Health and Wellness Practitioner Program I am starting in April at the World School of Massage in San Francisco. This program includes training and certifications in Massage Therapy, Energy and Somatic Massage and Holistic Life Coaching and I look forward to using all the skills I learn on this journey to help others heal and lead healthy and fulfilled lives.

My total tuition cost will be $15,000 and the World School is giving me a little bonus incentive. If I opt to pre-pay for the entire program they will allow me to complete their Teacher, Training and Coaching program for FREE! That means I receive a $3,850 training with an additional 500 hours of certification on them. This is both exciting and motivating and why my humble heart is setting the intention to raise the entire amount of my tuition so I can receive the extra training without the extra cost. With this in mind I have put a lot of time into creating the fun perks that you can receive for helping me reach my goal. (Please note, if you would like to claim multiple perks for yourself or to give as gifts you are able to make multiple contributions to claim more than one perk!)

If you would like to offer your support in additional ways please be liberal in sharing my campaign via email, Facebook, or Twitter. And also be sure to follow the link below to sign up for email updates from my blog Max Happy Jennie as I document my educational journey and share my growth and learning.

If you have any questions please don't hesitate to call, send me an email, or connect with me on Facebook. I thank you from the bottom of my heart for your time and consideration and send oodles of gratitude and abundance right back to you!

All the best,
Jennie

story:
Introducing the Native American Journalism Fellowship program

The Native American Journalists Association is pleased to announce an exciting program in partnership with the Newseum Institute. The goal is to help prepare Native American journalism students to enter the workforce by combining the expertise gained from two established programs: the former American Indian Journalism Institute, which was managed and funded by the Newseum Institute; and the Native American Journalists Association’s college student projects held at the annual NAJA conference. (See information below on Native Voices, the main training component of the fellowship.)

The two initiatives are melded into a single program designed to give students a range of journalism experiences during a one-year period. 

How it works 

1 . The project begins at the 2014 NAJA conference in Santa Clara, California. Students arrive early for a three-day series of sessions on the nuts and bolts of journalism. The training prepares them for their weeklong experience in covering the NAJA conference, where they also gain hands-on newsroom experience. Participants in NAJA’s student projects gain experience in putting out a newspaper at the conference and producing television and radio newscasts. 

2. NAJA-NI students get further training at the College Media Association’s multimedia workshops on the Vanderbilt campus, July 29 - Aug. 1. A special, one-day session designed specifically for Native students takes place in advance of the CMA training. (Dependent on whether we reach our funding goal.)

3. Students participate in at least four webinars designed to improve their journalism skills throughout the year. 

4. Selected students will have the option to enroll in a three-credit, 300-level online journalism course at the University of Montana geared specifically toward the NAJ fellows.

5. Mentors provide feedback and support during the year to help students get the most out of their experience. 

6. Students end their year at the 2015 NAJA conference and serve as senior staffers. The hope is to create an ongoing program in 2015; so as 2014 class graduates, a new group would start its year. 

NAJF Goals

  • Create a rich experience for Native American students that inspires them to pursue a career in journalism
  • Offer training that prepares students for the newsroom
  • Prepare participants for job offers (program graduates)
  • Execute a successful pilot program that turns into an ongoing program
  • Produce active NAJA professional members who contribute to the organization and become mentors to other aspiring journalists

What we need 

NAJA is requesting $10,000 from members, partners and individuals to make the first year of the NAJ Fellowship a success. (Note: This amount has been amended since the video pitch was produced.)

  • All funds raised will be used to support the travel, lodging, meals and technical support of the 2014 student projects. 
  • Even if NAJA doesn't meet the $10,000 mark, all funder donations will still be applied to paying for the students' expenses to Santa Clara, CA from all over the U.S. 

Please share with your circles

Every level of support is important. Even if you can't part with the cash, sharing this project with your personal and professional connections through social media can still make a great impact on the lives of Native students looking to change the world of journalism. 

About Native Voices

Native Voices for college students is an important career pipeline created specifically for aspiring Native American journalists. Each year, this program pairs students with professional journalists who often continue to provide academic and professional advice long after the program week ends.

NAJA’s student program is scheduled each year during the week of NAJA's annual conference. This year, the NAJA conference will take place at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Santa Clara, Calif., from July 10-13.

Students will work on stories under the guidance of mentors who are professional journalists. Stories produced by students during the conference will be published by NAJA in a printed newspaper and on our website. Students also gain hands-on experience in producing radio and television newscasts.

See the 2013 Native Voices student website

This project would provide multimedia training, hands-on journalism experience, webinars and mentoring in a way that recognizes and appreciates their cultural heritage.

About NAJA

The Native American Journalists Association is a non-profit organization that empowers journalists through the provision of resources to Native and non-Native media.

NAJA represents more than 350 members working in national and tribal media outlets, independent freelancers, associations, schools and other non-profit organizations through programs that promote diversity and defend challenges to free press, speech and expression.

NAJA is committed to increasing the representation of Native journalists in mainstream media. NAJA encourages both mainstream and tribal media to attain the highest standards of professionalism, ethics and responsibility.

Learn more at www.naja.com.

We are looking to add to our equipment for better live streams, finance more videos, events, promotional materials, running costs and help others live stream.

Multiple indy live stream events happening, including the debate from Lanark with Scotland's only Tory MP; Mark McGowan (Artist Taxi Driver); Mark Coburn (Indy Cyclist) and Wings Over Scotland Social 3, all can be viewed free at: http://new.livestream.com/IndependenceLive

Latest collaborative video production with Clan Destiny Films on John Jappy a civil servant in the 60s who looked after the Queens money. At the time, himself included, the general opinion amongst civil servants was that Scotland was dependent on money it received from Westminster. Then, he got access to the UK books and this was before oil...

Watch, think about it and share. John Jappy YouTube Playlist:
http://tiny.cc/gdj4fx

IN PRODUCTION: the latest economics video by Ivan McKee and vision for the future by Michelle Thomson of Business for Scotland, plus more short indy videos by the likes of Jonathon Shafi (RIC), Stephen J Watson (Academics for Indy), Bruce Morton (Comedian) and more...

story:
RAMS Need Your Help

The Ingraham Track and Field has doubled in size in the past 4 years and guess what... district funding for sports has not!  We've gone from 50 runners, jumpers, and throwers to over 100 and every one of those kids needs our support. Our funding from the district doesn't even cover transportation to the meets.

Wait, you ask?  What kind of costs does Track and Field have?

First of all, a unified team is a strong team and every athlete should have a jersey and warm-ups to wear proudly on meet day. 

    

But there's more to track and field than jerseys.....


We need poles for the vaulters, javelins and shot puts for the throwers and how about another canopy for those rainy, cold "spring" meets so that 50 kids aren't crowded under Antonio's training tent!

Can I Make a Difference?

YES!!!  Track and field is an accessible and inclusive sport that invites the seasoned and the newbie athlete alike to train, compete, improve and develop camaraderie and a sense of accomplishment.  Your generous participation in this campaign will help both our State Championship bound athletes and our kids running their first set of hurdles feel supported and part of something big.

Give What you Can

There are some great perks to thank you for your gift including a special offer from our fantastic coaches.  We also know that not everyone is in a position to give but you can still help by getting the word out and sharing this campaign with family and friends.

story:
Who the Heck Are You, and What's Going on Here?

Good question. I'm a 21 year old artist and aspiring teacher who is fascinated with learning languages and loves designing games. I'm experienced in pixel art and animation, music composing, and games programming (C# and Python). I also studied Chinese and Japanese in college, as well as a bit of German on my own. I have basic understanding of these three languages, but I want to travel to other countries and become fluent in their native languages, all while holding a job as an English teacher and (of course!) continuing my hobby of game development on the side. The first step is getting me to Germany where I can receive my CELTA certification and begin my career as an ESL teacher. This is where I need your help.

What I Need and What You Get

In order to achieve this goal, I need a fair amount of money since the German currency is stronger than the dollar. If fully funded, about 2,200$ will go towards the CELTA course itself. The rest will go towards my flight. Anything additional will be added to my current savings to help leverage my first few months of rent while in Germany, since I will spend the first four weeks there in my CELTA course and, as a result, will not have an income until after the first month.

What's in it for you? Well, for starters, I'll be running a blog about my travels. If you're interested in foreign countries, I'll be going out of my way to do as much research on the language, culture, and history of each country I live in and I'll prepare all sorts of blog posts regarding these things, including any pictures I manage to take.

If that doesn't interest you, I've got a variety of perks related to my personal game development activities. I'll be opening up a private game dev blog to certain backers that I'll update with content on a weekly basis, which will contain all sorts of cool things like my animation work:

Or cool tunes I've written for my games like the following:

https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/gac1j1ozsn0...

as well as plenty of other content such as concept art, level layouts, and even early access to playable versions of games I'm working on.

The Impact

If I make it to Germany, I think I'll be one brilliant teacher and game developer. I have a desire to learn many languages and explore many places. I'll use these experiences to help and teach others, and I'll take inspiration from my travels to create beautiful works of art through interactive storytelling. If I get established in Germany and start off my career as a teacher, my life will have finally started. I'll be happy and have an exciting career, and what that means for all of you is I'll cheerfully be able to put out amazing content. Let my animation and music speak for themselves, I am more than capable of making something cool for everyone to enjoy-- my life and my inspiration just need to be in the right place. So please, help me blossom. I promise that your money absolutely will not go to waste.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word through any social network, if you have one available. Use the Indiegogo share tools, tell a friend, anything. Even the smallest contributions are appreciated.
story_txt: Who the Heck Are You, and What's Going on Here?Good question. I'm a 21 year old artist and aspiring teacher who is fascinated with learning languages and loves designing games. I'm experienced in pixel art and animation, music composing, and games programming (C# and Python). I also studied Chinese and Japanese in college, as well as a bit of German on my own. I have basic understanding of these three languages, but I want to travel to other countries and become fluent in their native languages, all while holding a job as an English teacher and (of course!) continuing my hobby of game development on the side. The first step is getting me to Germany where I can receive my CELTA certification and begin my career as an ESL teacher. This is where I need your help.What I Need and What You GetIn order to achieve this goal, I need a fair amount of money since the German currency is stronger than the dollar. If fully funded, about 2,200$ will go towards the CELTA course itself. The rest will go towards my flight. Anything additional will be added to my current savings to help leverage my first few months of rent while in Germany, since I will spend the first four weeks there in my CELTA course and, as a result, will not have an income until after the first month.What's in it for you? Well, for starters, I'll be running a blog about my travels. If you're interested in foreign countries, I'll be going out of my way to do as much research on the language, culture, and history of each country I live in and I'll prepare all sorts of blog posts regarding these things, including any pictures I manage to take.If that doesn't interest you, I've got a variety of perks related to my personal game development activities. I'll be opening up a private game dev blog to certain backers that I'll update with content on a weekly basis, which will contain all sorts of cool things like my animation work:Or cool tunes I've written for my games like the following:https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/gac1j1ozsn0...as well as plenty of other content such as concept art, level layouts, and even early access to playable versions of games I'm working on.The ImpactIf I make it to Germany, I think I'll be one brilliant teacher and game developer. So please, help me blossom. I promise that your money absolutely will not go to waste.Other Ways You Can HelpSpread the word through any social network, if you have one available. Use the Indiegogo share tools, tell a friend, anything. Even the smallest contributions are appreciated.

story:
FREE EDUCATION IS IN FASHION

Creative Space Beirut (CSB) is a free, non profit school for fashion design. We provide quality design education to talented individuals who lack the resources to pursue their aspirations.

Our students dedicate three years to the program, attending weekdays from 9 am - 5pm. They are provided with a well-rounded curriculum, exposure into the design world, supplies and transportation entirely free of charge.

Our long term goal is to expand into a multifaceted and progressive institution that provides free quality education in various fields of creative design.


THE IMPORTANCE OF ACCESSIBLE DESIGN EDUCATION

Design is a process used to shape and structure our world; the clothes we wear, the buildings we live and work in and the products we use. In order for design to be an effective tool for the progress of society, it must be inclusive, incorporating the visions and voices of people from varying walks of life.

Design thinking is empowering. It encourages creative thought and progressive solutions. It allows individuals agency in their lives and develops important mental capabilities for problem-solving. Free design education provides those who lack the  resources to pursue costly studies with the tools required to remain in step with the advancement of society and helps ensure a diversified roster of voices in the industry, promoting a more heterogeneously designed world.

The intention behind CSB is to strive to make the design world accessible to young people with talent, flair and the driving impulse to create. Considering the high costs of tuition at design institutions, the cost of the supplies required to carry out an education and pursue a career, and the impenetrability of the design industry, it is impossible for many aspiring designers from marginalised communities to pursue their talent. Currently design education and access to the design world are reserved for those who can afford to get a foot in. Because wealth and aptitude do not necessarily come hand in hand, the world is therefore missing out on plenty of untapped talent. CSB provides a system that fosters the talent of those who might otherwise be left unnoticed.

                               

A first year student's sketches 
HOW IT ALL BEGAN

With these notions in mind, Sarah Hermez and her former professor, design guru Caroline Simonelli, founded Creative Space Beirut in 2011.

In 2009, Sarah graduated with a dual degree in Fashion Design from Parsons the New School for Design and Media and Culture studies from Eugene Lang the New School for Liberal Arts. Disillusioned by the corporate face of fashion, she resolved to make positive use of her privileged education and to take steps towards reforming the nature of the industry.  



The idea began brewing over a cup of coffee with Caroline at Dean and Deluca during a visit to New York, a year after Sarah had graduated. As they sat sorting through schemes for merging Sarah's seemingly irreconcilable passions of fashion design and social justice, Caroline suddenly asked 'why don't you start a free school?'


There, the seed was planted. Sarah returned to her native Lebanon and with a burst of energy and conviction she began drafting plans, conducting research and garnering support.  Through visits to refugee camps, women's centres, marginalised neighbourhoods and NGOs Sarah found five young aspiring designers from various backgrounds who were passionate and courageous enough to begin this journey with her.


Caroline and Sarah guiding the students during the first days of Creative Space Beirut


In June 2011, Caroline flew in from New York with $100,000 worth of quality fabric donated by designers Donna Karan, Derek Lam and Diane von Furstenberg. Together they set out on an experiment that was to set the precedent for Creative Space Beirut. Within three months, 30 one-of-a-kind pieces were designed and executed by the students and an exhibition was curated and held at Saifi Urban Gardens in August. Every piece was sold, raising over 20,0000 to help fund the next term!

The moral support of the public, the success of the exhibition, and the students' energy, dedication and raw talent confirmed Sarah's belief in the importance of free education and provided the impetus and motivation to soldier on to the next step.


Members of the public admire student pieces at pilot project exhibition, Saifi Urban Gardens, August 2011


Cofounders' Biographies

Sarah Hermez is a Lebanese fashion designer, born and raised in Kuwait. She pursued dual degrees in fashion design at Parsons the New School for Design and media/cultural studies at Eugene Lang the New School for Liberal Arts in New York.  She moved to Beirut in 2010 and launched Creative Space Beirut, merging the two worlds she is passionate about and bridging the social and the creative industries. She continues to direct the program and act as mentor to the students. Sarah is also the co-founder of SECOND .st, a socially conscious brand with a progressive take on the classic shirt.

Caroline Shlala-Simonelli is a Lebanese/American designer who teaches fashion design at Parsons the New School for Design in New York. Before teaching, Caroline had a long career as a fashion designer in women’s dress apparel. Along with her own line of volume and couture collection, Large Sizes for Q V C , Bloomingdales and Saks fifth avenue, she was also Head Dress Designer at Liz Claiborne and Head Collection Designer at Mollie Parnis New York. Caroline travels from New York to Beirut twice a year to lend her expertise and experience to Creative Space Beirut.



WHERE WE ARE NOW 

Over the past four years since the initial success of the pilot project and through an ongoing series of trial and error, we have evolved into a three year program with a rich and progressive curriculum.  By embedding technical skills into the creative process, we have developed a holistic approach to design education that allows for abundant creative freedom and encourages agency and collaboration through peer to peer exchange. 

Through this progressive method, we have created an innovative space that fosters dialogue between our diverse students, nurtures their talent and helps them transform their passions into solid skills.


Student sketching in a live model drawing class

We now have ten students who produce their own work under the mentorship of a team of local and international artists and designers. We have been lucky enough to receive the continuous support of creative individuals who believe in our initiative, our students and the importance of free education. They've volunteered their time as temporary or permanent mentors, giving courses such as pattern making, knitting, embroidery, silk workshops, concept courses and much more.  Caroline continues to fly in from New York for two months every year to teach the final course and help curate the exhibitions. Our students have had the privilege to learn from both established and up and coming designers, not only adding to their skill set, but also gaining insight into the design world through the formation of fruitful and lasting relationships and engagement with the design community.  

At the end of each year, the students' one of a kind pieces are showcased and sold in a public exhibition. 100 % of the proceeds generated during exhibitions are reinvested into the program. This way we are able to help sustain the  and ensure our students’ continued free education. Since our beginnings in 2011, we have held six exhibitions in various prestigious local venues, and one in Kuwait. (To see some of the student designs, please go to the gallery page here or on our website!)



After completing the three year program, students will have gained a quality design education and compiled a comprehensive portfolio, and are assisted in locating career opportunities through CSB's endorsement and network.


COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT

In accordance with our values of collaboration, we strive to play a role in the community through taking part in conferences, festivals, and other events with like-minded individuals. We have been an active part of Beirut Design Week for two years, and plan on continuing to do so in order to maintain dialogue with the local and international design community. Our founder Sarah also gave talks and took part in various conferences, including TEDxBeirut, the Nuqat Conference in Kuwait, and ING Creatives Conference in Dubai. It is important for us to spread our message, and to become involved in the dynamic discourse of responsible design, free education, and equal opportunity.  

CSB founder Sarah Hermez gives a talk at TEDxBeirut 



OUR STUDENTS

Our students come from diverse backgrounds and commute to CSB from all corners of Lebanon, including Palestinian refugee camps, Saida and Bourj Hammoud. Our students do not have the means to pursue an education or career in fashion design; however, they share a talent and aptitude for design and demonstrate a commitment to hard work. CSB offers these talented young individuals a unique opportunity into design education as well as the design industry. In a country fraught by sectarian tension, with 18 different religious sects, CSB offers a haven of mutual acceptance and understanding that promotes equality and diversity through creative education. Our students form strong friendships, break religious, social and economic barriers, build bridges across communities, and find constructive common ground in their passion for design.

      CSB students help each other with a pattern making assignment




Aline joined the Creative Space Beirut team in November 2013. She quickly proved her dedication, impressing her mentors with her work ethic and quick learning. Within the first month, Aline's technical prowess was evident. She has surpassed expectations on every technique she's come across, excelling in precision and cleanliness. Aline works slowly and carefully, ensuring that each stitch is perfect. We are confident in Aline's capability to become a strong, expert designer and look forward to supporting her coming accomplishments. 


Ahmad's fascination with fashion began with a penchant for illustration at the tender age of three, when he would draw his mother's dresses and outfits and make clothes for dolls. Though his parents encouraged his talent, they could not afford to pay for an education in fashion design or for the supplies and materials required for the degree. Ahmad joined CSB this year and has already impressed his peers and mentors with his talent for illustration. Through an enriching education, we have no doubt he can be well on his way to becoming an accomplished designer. 


Dana grew up making clothes for her dolls out of napkins, scrap fabric and household items. Her drive to become a fashion designer grew when she saw Lebanese designers such as Elie Saab and Zouheir Mourad rise to worldwide success. Her family could not afford any of the costly fashion design programs that are offered in Lebanon. Dana joined CSB this year and we are excited to see what she will make of her quirky aesthetics and enthusiasm for design. 


Fatima taught herself to sew and worked under a tailor for three months before she realised that it didn't allow for much creativity or growth. Set on learning to design, she joined CSB in February 2013 and has since displayed rapid development and incomparable work ethic, Fatima takes naturally to intricate and detail-oriented techniques such as embroidery and material work, which entails forming added textures onto fabric. Her paced, dexterous and determined method of design is apparent in her refined pieces, which speak for a careful and studied aspiring fashion designer. 


Hazem's passion for fashion was born in childhood, when he would insist on styling his mother, delighting in choosing her outfits for different occasions. Although his parents supported his penchant for design, his mother insisted on his entering Lebanese International University through government aid. A dedicated worker with big dreams, Hazem will continue his degree in business while also pursuing his ambition of becoming a fashion designer here at CSB. 


Heba joined CSB in November 2013. She had never designed before, but her talent was evident in her sketches. In the past year, Heba has continued to develop and to impress us with her ability to integrate her fertile imagination into her designs. Seamlessly weaving the conceptual and the technical, Heba's modern pieces reflect forward thinking as she designs with both function and beauty in mind. She works hard to strengthen her technique, as she challenges herself to push towards the frontiers of conceptual design. 


Marie reached out to CSB through the Kfarhay branch of SOS Village d'Enfants, the relief organisation whose care she has been under since becoming orphaned under unknown circumstances at the age of 2. Marie is our youngest student and has been interested in fashion design for as long as she can remember. She takes pleasure in altering her own clothes, snipping and sewing her jeans, tops, skirts and dresses to create new designs. Inspired by her determination and enthusiasm we welcomed her to the team this year. 


Nour became interested in CSB after she saw our 'Make Designers Not Clothes'  slogan in graffiti on walls around the city. It struck a chord with her and she sought us out. When she came in for her initial interview, Nour brought with her an array of unique and crafty sculptures and pieces of jewellery, as well as a thick portfolio of drawings and sketches. Undoubtedly in possession of a creative mind and skilled hands, we welcomed her into CSB in November 2013. Nour's designs are intricate and eclectic, integrating techniques such as macramé and knotting into her pieces. 


A passionate colour enthusiast, Rola has always experimented in working with her hands, employing several artistic crafts. She joined the Creative Space Beirut in February 2013 after attending a local institute for design. Since then, she has strengthened her skills and is always surprising us with her creativity. Rola designs off the beaten track, experimenting with patchwork and creating her own fabrics. Last year, she received 2nd place in a national design competition and won a prize to attend Paris Fashion Week! Rola will be producing her own collection and graduating this year. 


Rony grew up dreaming to be a fashion designer, making clothes out of household items, sketching and researching fashion trends on his own. In his time at the Creative Space Beirut since February 2013, Rony has come a very long way. A quick learner and a natural leader, Rony has not only designed a number of popular pieces, but also assists his fellow student designers with pattern making. Last year, Rony won first place in a national fashion design competition in which four other design schools participated. As a prize, he was sent to Milan to participate in a workshop at the prestigious academy, NABA. We have very high hopes for Rony, who continues to develop as a designer, challenging himself and excelling at each endeavour he tackles.


FUNDRAISING STRATEGY

In the future, CSB aims to become a self sustainable entity.

Currently, we persist largely through student based scholarships from generous individuals who believe in our cause. The generosity of these individuals is crucial to us.

However, as not all of our students are covered by scholarships, we have developed a rigorous fundraising strategy that helps us cover the remainder of our yearly costs.

Events - We host quarterly fundraising events in collaboration with various venues in Beirut.  


CSB Brand - CSB has developed a brand under the same name including a ready to wear line and a product line, designed by the creative team. The ready to wear line includes one size fits all, casual and comfortable items will donate all profits to CSB's educational program.


Exhibitions - Each year, we collaborate with a different venue and host a public exhibition displaying the student’s collection. The students’ one of a kind designs are sold, and the proceeds generated are returned to the school.


HOW YOU CAN HELP 

As we continue to work towards self-sustainability, we need as much support as possible from those who believe in our cause and in the change that free creative education can bring about in people's lives and in our future.  The $25,000 we aim to raise through crowdfunding will sustain our organization until our November exhibition in Kuwait, our largest fundraising event of the year. Over the course of 5 months, these funds will cover student transportation, student supplies,  rent and utilities. Additionally, the money you help us raise will partially cover salaries, costs related to a visiting international instructor, and expenses related to our exhibition such as student flight tickets to Kuwait.  

To continue supporting the talent of these amazing students, we need your help! It is actually inspired by a very old way of doing things, artists have always had patrons.

In addition to being a collaborative, grassroots method of raising funds, crowdfunding is also another avenue through which to spread our message about the importance of free creative education. 

Thank you and we hope that as pioneers of a better future, you will join us in paving the road towards equal opportunity!

In the future, CSB aims to become a self sustainable entity.Currently, we persist largely through student based scholarships from generous individuals who believe in our cause. The generosity of these individuals is crucial to us.However, as not all of our students are covered by scholarships, we have developed a rigorous fundraising strategy that helps us cover the remainder of our yearly costs.Events - We host quarterly fundraising events in collaboration with various venues in Beirut.  CSB Brand - CSB has developed a brand under the same name including a ready to wear line and a product line, designed by the creative team. The ready to wear line includes one size fits all, casual and comfortable items will donate all profits to CSB's educational program.Exhibitions - Each year, we collaborate with a different venue and host a public exhibition displaying the student’s collection. The students’ one of a kind designs are sold, and the proceeds generated are returned to the school.HOW YOU CAN HELP 
As we continue to work towards self-sustainability, we need as much support as possible from those who believe in our cause and in the change that free creative education can bring about in people's lives and in our future.  The $25,000 we aim to raise through crowdfunding will sustain our organization until our November exhibition in Kuwait, our largest fundraising event of the year. Over the course of 5 months, these funds will cover student transportation, student supplies,  rent and utilities. Additionally, the money you help us raise will partially cover salaries, costs related to a visiting international instructor, and expenses related to our exhibition such as student flight tickets to Kuwait.  
To continue supporting the talent of these amazing students, we need your help! It is actually inspired by a very old way of doing things, artists have always had patrons.
In addition to being a collaborative, grassroots method of raising funds, crowdfunding is also another avenue through which to spread our message about the importance of free creative education. 
Thank you and we hope that as pioneers of a better future, you will join us in paving the road towards equal opportunity!

story:
535 interns on Capitol Hill — that's what we want! Emerge 535 is the campaign of the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, Incorporated (CBCF) to place 535 African-American interns on Capitol Hill.  

 Why do we want 535 interns on Capitol Hill? 

The origins of the CBCF’s internship program were to address underrepresentation of minorities on Capitol Hill and its link to public policy decisions impacting communities of color.

In short, individuals leave the program better informed about how our federal government and the public policy process and the impact of federal policies on communities of color. 

Interns who pursue public policy careers upon graduation gain institutional knowledge, practical experience and skill sets.

 Placing 535 future leaders throughout the halls of Congress will: 

  • Demonstrate the commitment to diversity in all facets of public policy;
  • Expand academic, leadership, and professional development opportunities for emerging black leaders;
  • Equip students with professional experience in public service;
  • Provide students with first-hand leadership experience by working with seasoned leaders in Washington, DC; and,
  • Prepare students to be informed advocates who shape our world.

You may not know it, but the CBCF has a proven track record of producing leaders through its Leadership for Public Service program (Leadership Institute).  In 2014, the CBCF placed 72 students in public service internships, 18 fellowships and provided 379 scholarships totaling $612,700.

The best and the brightest students have so much to offer and there is still so much work to be done. Recent reports indicate the 

535 seems like a lofty goal, but, with your support, if we incrementally increase our intern placements each year, we will achieve that goal. 

We can't do it without YOU! 

We've made it easy for you — you can give $15, $53, $135, $535, $1,535 or even $5,350.

We (that includes you) are going to produce 535 leaders who will make a difference on behalf of African Americans.

Thank you for your support!

story:
My name is Rana AlSaleh and I'm a translator from Palestine. I always had a dream of studying a Master degree in Human Rights in the UK.  

what course and why?

I belong to a refugee family and I know how hard it is for many refugees to be lacking most of basic rights. I want to be one of those young people who makes a difference in this world. I want to help people and make a difference in their lives. I want to help people get the basic rights they don't have like education, proper food, clean water and medicine etc  My focus will be women, children and refugees.. I already had admission for a course:  MLL in International Human Rights and Social Justice at London Metropolitan University. My only problem is that I lack full funding. I have paid the university half of my tuition, i have the other half already and I'm looking to fund part of the rest. 

what I need:

The money I need will cover part of living costs (travel costs from Palestine to the UK and back, accommodation, daily expenses, university money for books, stationary, materials needed for study etc),  Help me to help others by pursuing my education in the UK. Your donations will make a difference., Spread the word and be part of this future dream. 


My course starts in January 2015. 

However, UK system says I should have all the money to proceed with Visa and all. I'm getting time limited as I need to restart my procedures again in November to have enough time for all. I hope you can help. I'm ready to work in return of this . for further details let me know.  

Below is a copy of the offer.

best regards,

---------------------------------------------

story:
Hello dear network and everybody else who might fall upon this page!

In August 2015 I'm travelling to Sri Lanka alongside the educational organisation SL Volunteers, to spend a month tailoring and teaching creative movement-based workshops to children with disabilities, with the goal to offer the children a different view on their bodies and abilities.

For those of you who don't know me, I am a contemporary dance student at Trinity Laban Conservatoire for Music and Dance in London, finishing my BA in July. Through my studies I have become hugely interested in how a playful exploration of physical contact can help prevent social isolation between children. This project gives me a chance to develop and use my skills in a way that hopefully will improve the quality of life for many children. 

In Sri Lanka, it is unfortunately very common for people with physical and mental disabilities to become excluded from society. The focus of this project is to help the children gain confidence, meet others in a similar situation, enhance teamworking skills, explore new ways of learning and doing, and most importantly, getting a positive experience with their bodies.

In order to make this project a reality I need your help. 
I'm looking to fundraise 500 GBP to cover the costs of flights between London and Colombo, and every little penny would be warmly appreciated.

All best, 

Natalie                                         

                                              





                             

                                             SPECIMEN by Rachel Kuik, 2014

                                     

                                                        Lulu Art Group, 2011

                                        

                                       NOMAD'S LAND by Laura Ganotis, 2014

                            

                            RIDE OF MOMENTUM by Natalie Sloth Richter, 2014

story:
The Adelphia Men.

Our names are Christopher Robinson, Kyland Rowland, Dustin Ramsey, Scott Sanchez, Ryan Overall, Jayce Likin, Don Lott, Nick South, Caleb Hettinga, Michael Eckblad, Derek Hudon, and Andrew Hawkison.

We are the 12 men of Adelphia Bible School and we are attempting to go on a trip to Ireland at the end of April. 

The Basics of the Trip.

We need $28,800 as a whole for this trip. But in 12 days we need to raise 80% of that which is $17,240 and that is minus the fundraising we have already accomplished. This is a challenge, we know. But we believe that God will provide a way for this to happen. 

If we are blessed to go we will be providing a blog for you to follow our trip, we will be making a collage of photos and videos which selected donors will receive, personal thank you letters, and more.

The Impact

The impact you will have on this trip will be enormous! You will be a part of God working in 12 men who are on their way to becoming pastors, missionaries, youth leaders, or even just being able to provide God to people in our everyday lives! We believe God will provide a way.

The Challenge

Our biggest challenge is the fact that we have 12 days to raise $17,240. The reasoning behind this deadline is strictly because airfare is the cheapest at the time of the end date. There is no doubt in our minds that God is going to work something in this. It's just a fact. 

Prayer can help us too!

Prayer. The power of prayer is so powerful! Jesus Himself talked about if you have the faith of a mustard seed then you can tell a mountain to move and it will. We have the faith but prayer is always welcome!


"Show me a man who is well traveled and I will show you a man who knows the lies of his own village."

C.S. Lewis

story:
HI Everyone,

My name is Linda Lee and I am the writer, illustrator, narrator and animator of a brand new animated children's ebook call "Serengeti Safari". I am an independent animation artist that loves to watch and create cartoons. Just last year I created a public service announcement (PSA) about Japan's 2010 tsunami. The PSA was nominated for Best Commercial at the 2011 Burbank International Film Festival in Burbank, California, USA. 

Description and Importance of this campaign-

The format of my animated ebook will look like a short film except it will have text on the pictures, narration, limited animation and the best part is that it will look like one of Disneyland's slow motion roller coaster rides. The ebook for now can be view only on the web. If it's a success I will upgrade the ebook to mobile apps.

The main reason for this campaign is to raise money to publish my animated children's ebook. I also would like to create animated contents that are fun and educational at the same time. No matter what age you are today, we've all got our knowledge from text books, magazines, fiction and non- fiction books. I still think paper copy books are great, but I would like to change that a little bit so that children of this and later generations can have more fun while reading.

Another important thing about this campaign is that if I have extra funds from this campaign. I want to give 10% of the extra funds  to LA Zoo. I like to draw the animals at LA Zoo and I have also seen how happy children of any age are when they go to the zoo to see animals that they don't usually see in their daily lives.

What I need and what you get for your contributions-

For your contributions you will also get the perks listed in the list of perks. Just to name a couple of these perks if you contribute $10 or more you will get a 3x5 hand illustrated Thank you card from me the author and if you contribute $25 or more you will get your name listed in the credits' page at the end of the ebook as well as a signed DVD copy of the ebook.

I am very passionate about animation, but this campaign is not only about my passion. It's about how I can create jobs for artistic people like me, helping children learn and hopefully protect the animals world wide from extinction. This campaign is also about helping LA Zoo become a better and safer place for animals to live in.

Please help with either money donations or simply just spreading the word about this campaign Thank you.

Sincerely,

 

Linda Lee

story:
About K's 4 Kids

One in five Aussie kids is abused - K's 4 Kids wants you to help us raise funds to:

  • pay for therapy for abused kids
  • establish a 1300 number to support survivors and their families
  • raise awareness and help reduce the incidence of childhood abuse

 

How your support will make a difference

Not only will you receive your perk but Project KidSafe will provide the following:

  • Project KidSafe Brochures to go into Aussie Schools
  • Free support for families of kids abused
  • Allow Project KidSafe to kick off our free 1300 line

Even if we don't get the $20k goal - your donation will be put to good use towards the above anyway!

Why support K's 4 Kids

Angry Anderson and Dr Jodi Death is heading the ride from Coolangatta to Sydney - Jodi and Angry are both survivors of childhood abuse. So nobody knows better about why we need your help!  Child abuse affects the entire community in many ways.  Children who survive abuse can suffer the following:

  • Depression and other mental health disorders
  • Homelessness
  • Anger
  • Inability to maintain relationships
  • Inability to complete education
  • Substance abuse and addictions
  • Much more

Other Ways You Can Help

You may want to help protect kids in other ways - so here's some ideas:

  • Spread the word about K's 4 Kids
  • Join our facebook page
  • Follow us on Twitter
  • Volunteer for Project KidSafe

And dont forget Indiegogo has some great tools which will help you to share our campaign - so please use them!

Thanks for your support - Australia's kids THANK YOU!!

story:
The editor of LSU's student newspaper has filed a lawsuit against the university, seeking the release of the names of candidates for the university's top position. We are trying to raise money to cover the filing fees for that lawsuit. We believe these records are public under Louisiana law, and allowing LSU to avoid releasing them sets a dangerous precedent for secrecy at the state’s largest public university.

Daily Reveille editor Andrea Gallo is a student. She is filing this lawsuit individually, and is not backed by the resources of a large news organization. We hope to aid Gallo's fight for openness by ensuring she does not have to worry about legal fees.

LSU began a search in late 2012 for someone to head both the LSU System and the main campus in Baton Rouge. This was a new position that combined what used to be two jobs, and as the newspaper of record for LSU, The Daily Reveille sought to cover that search aggressively.

On March 6, 2013, Gallo filed a public records request with the LSU Board of Supervisors, asking for records on all applicants for the position of LSU System president/chancellor. The board denied the request, claiming that the records on finalists for the position were kept by a private search firm, R. William Funk & Associates. Gallo filed suit on April 1.

Scott Sternberg, Gallo's attorney, has told news outlets that using a private firm to conduct public duties is a way to keep issues out of the public eye, but the method still violates the spirit and letter of the state's open records law.

Please consider donating whatever you can. Our goal is set at $1,200, which only covers the initial filing fees. We expect many more legal fees to accrue as the case continues through the court system, so please don't stop donating once we reach our goal. And please share this with LSU students, faculty, journalists and anyone else who believes in transparency at public institutions.

Sincerely,

Alumni of The Daily Reveille / LSU

NOTE: If we raise more funds than needed to cover legal expenses, or if Gallo's lawsuit is successful and she is awarded all her legal fees, the money collected will be donated to the Reveille Alumni Association, an organization of LSU graduates and former Reveille staffers that focuses on journalism training, networking and scholarships.


More information: http://www.splc.org/news/newsflash.asp?id=2554

story:
The world lost a great man, Josh Richardson.  But his son, Will, lost more than all of us, his loving father.  Please help by contributing to Will's college fund.

We set our goal at $5000 to keep the funding fees lower - we want as much money to go to Will as possible.  We are really hoping we can raise way above and beyond that goal. 

Josh definately wanted the best for Will.  This fund is the least we can do after his passing.  

The following is a quote from Josh that will help inspire us all.

"Over the last few days I have seen so many post of parents applauding their child's accomplishments of all A's, A-B Honor Roll, best athlete (only in West Monroe, SMH), Citizenship, most Christ-like, etc. be proud of your kids, I am proud that Will made all A's again. A tip of parenting advice though, be proud of your kids and tell them how much you love them EVERY DAY! and even if your kids got zero awards, by no means are they a failure. I am way more proud of my son for what he attempts when the odds are against him. I am proud my son is not afraid to work to get better over any accomplishment he has.  

Michael Jordan said: I have missed over 9,000 shots, I have lost more than 300 games, 26 times I've been trusted to take the game-winning shot and missed. I've failed over and over and over again in my life...and THAT is why I succeed.  

I love you Will, and every other kid who is not afraid of failure because in the long run, that is what will make you a success."

-- Josh Richardson

story:
The EDGE Green Masquerade Ball is to benefit 13,300 children in 10 countries (The USA, Jamaica, Haiti, Kenya, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Guatemala, India, Puerto Rico and Madagascar) through education, environmental awareness and humanitarian services, provided by the EDGE Charitable Foundation, a 501c3.

The Ball is set for Saturday, November 3rd, 2012 in Miami, Florida. The theme is Alice in Wonderland. We have live performers, best costume contest, organic hookah, 2 DJ's, silent auction, open bar and great food! 

Our goal is to raise $50,000 for the Ball to offset cost for decorations, food, liquor, film production and many more event costs so it does not impact funding raised and needed for our green curriculum development, program development and donation drives for our children in low income settings around the worldwide.

Because it has become more and more difficult to raise needed funds for our services in this competitive economy your support means a lot to us to continue doing the good we are doing.

If you are unable to donate but know a company who would like to sponsor our event please email us at info@theedgeeducation.com. 

Other ways to help:

November 16th: EDGE Food Drive - for support migrant and domestic abuse victims in South Florida.

December 2012: EDGE Children for Children Toy Drive - in partnership with the Hispanic Police Officers Association of Miami Dade - to support migrant families, domestic abuse victims and human trafficking victims in South Florida.

January 27, 2012: ING Miami Marathons. The EDGE is a Participating Charity of the ING. Run with TEAM EDGE and help us raise $5,000 by running the full or half marathon.

April 2013: Earth Month Education Campaign - produced by EDGE interns to teach important environmental topics to preschoolers.

We are always looking for ways to support our children out of the country. Our newest country, Madagascar is our next stop to provide humanitarian services.

THANK YOU!!!
